Utterance: Welcome back! How have you been since our last session?
Hi! I’ve been okay. I’ve been trying to do some painting and writing like we talked about.
That’s fantastic! How has that experience been for you?
It’s been really nice. I forgot how much I enjoy expressing myself that way. It feels freeing.
I’m so glad to hear that! Engaging in creative activities can be very therapeutic. Have you noticed any changes in your feelings of dependency since you started these activities?
Yes, I think I feel a bit more independent. It’s like I’m finding joy in my own space, which is new for me.
That’s a significant shift! It sounds like you’re starting to embrace your own company. How does that feel emotionally?
It’s a relief, honestly. I feel less anxious about being alone and more excited about what I can create.
That’s wonderful progress! Have you had any moments where you felt the urge to rely on someone else, and how did you handle it?
There was a moment when I wanted to call a friend to hang out, but I decided to stay home and paint instead. I felt good about that choice.
That’s a great example of self-reliance! It shows you’re becoming more comfortable with solitude. Are there any other challenges you’re facing?
I still struggle with sleep. I tried meditating before bed, but I still wake up a lot.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Physiological Observations

Utterance: It’s good that you’re trying new methods. Sleep issues can take time to improve. Have you considered keeping a sleep journal to track patterns?
No, I haven’t. What would that involve?
A sleep journal can help you identify triggers that affect your sleep. You can note when you go to bed, when you wake up, and any factors that might have influenced your sleep quality.
That sounds like a good idea. I’ll give it a try.
Great! It could provide valuable insights. Let’s also revisit your anger management. Have you encountered any situations where you felt anger arise?
Yes, I had a small argument with a family member. I felt the anger bubbling up, but I remembered to take a breath and respond calmly.
That’s a significant achievement! How did you feel after handling it that way?
I felt proud of myself. It was nice to not let the anger control me.
That’s a powerful realization! Recognizing your emotions and choosing how to respond is a sign of growth. How do you feel about continuing to work on this?
I want to keep improving. It’s nice to feel in control of my reactions.
Absolutely! Let’s continue to build on those skills. Would you like to set a specific goal for the next week regarding your anger or emotional responses?
I’d like to practice pausing for a moment before reacting in any situation that frustrates me.
That sounds like a solid goal! Remember, it’s about progress, not perfection. How do you plan to remind yourself to pause?
Maybe I can set reminders on my phone or use sticky notes around the house.
That’s a great idea! Visual reminders can be very effective. Let’s also talk about your creative pursuits. How can you integrate them into your daily routine?
I think I’ll set aside specific times during the week to paint or write. Maybe twice a week?
That sounds perfect! Committing to a schedule can help you prioritize those activities. How does that feel to you?
It feels exciting! I’m looking forward to it.
I’m glad to hear that! Remember, this is about nurturing yourself. Let’s check in on your sleep and emotional responses next session.
Sounds good! Thank you.
You’re doing great work. I look forward to hearing about your progress. Take care until next time!
